HTMLElement.summary: The HTMLElement interface represents any HTML element. Some elements directly implement this interface, while others implement it via an interface that inherits it.

HTMLElementAccessKey.summary: The HTMLElement.accessKey property sets the keystroke which a user can press to jump to a given element.

blockquote.para: The HTMLElement.accessKey property is seldom used because of its multiple conflicts with already present key bindings in browsers. To work around this, browsers implement accesskey behavior if the keys are pressed with other "qualifying" keys (such as <kbd>Alt</kbd> + accesskey).

remarks.para: -HTML global attribute: accesskey

HTMLElementAccessKeyLabel.summary:
The HTMLElement.accessKeyLabel
read-only property returns a string containing the element's
browser-assigned access key (if any); otherwise it returns an empty string.

remarks.para:
-
-The accesskey global
attribute.

HTMLElementAnchorElement.summary: CAUTION Non-standard The anchorElement property of the interface returns a reference to the element's anchor element. This works only in the case of elements associated with their anchors via the anchor HTML attribute, not elements associated with their anchors via the CSS anchor-name and position-anchor properties.

remarks.para:
-HTML anchor attribute
-CSS anchor-name and position-anchor properties
-CSS anchor positioning module

HTMLElementAnchorElement.value: An instance representing the element's anchor element, or null if it doesn't have one.

HTMLElementAttachInternals.summary:
The HTMLElement.attachInternals() method returns an object.
This method allows a custom element to participate in HTML forms. The ElementInternals interface provides utilities for working with these elements in the same way you would work with any standard HTML form element, and also exposes the Accessibility Object Model to the element.

remarks.para:
-More capable form controls
-Creating custom form controls with ElementInternals

HTMLElementAttributeStyleMap.summary: The attributeStyleMap read-only property of the interface returns a live object that contains a list of style properties of the element that are defined in the element's inline style attribute, or assigned using the property of the interface via script.

remarks.para: Shorthand properties are expanded. If you set border-top: 1px solid black, the longhand properties (border-top-color, border-top-style, and border-top-width) are set instead.
The main difference between property and attributeStyleMap property is that, the style property will return a object, while the attributeStyleMap property will return a object.
Though the property itself is not writable, you could read and write inline styles through the object that it returns, just like through the object that returns via the style property.

HTMLElementAutocapitalize.summary: The autocapitalize property of the interface represents the element's capitalization behavior for user input. It is available on all HTML elements, though it doesn't affect all of them, including:

remarks.para: autocapitalize doesn't affect behavior when typing on a physical keyboard. It affects the behavior of other input mechanisms such as virtual keyboards on mobile devices and voice input. This can assist users by making data entry quicker and easier, for example by automatically capitalizing the first letter of each sentence.
It reflects the value of the autocapitalize HTML global attribute.
-autocapitalize HTML global attribute

HTMLElementAutocapitalize.value: A string that represents the element's capitalization behavior for user input. Valid values are as follows:

HTMLElementAutocorrect.summary: The autocorrect property of the interface controls whether or not autocorrection of editable text is enabled for spelling and/or punctuation errors.

remarks.para:
The specific autocorrection behavior, including which words are substituted, depends on the user agent and the services provided by the underlying device.
For example, on macOS a user agent might rely on registered replacement text and punctuation.
Other devices and browsers may use a different approach.
The property reflects the value of the autocorrect HTML global attribute.
-autocapitalize HTML global attribute

HTMLElementAutocorrect.value: true if auto-correction is enabled for the element, and false otherwise.

HTMLElementAutofocus.summary: The autofocus property of the interface represents a boolean value reflecting the autofocus HTML global attribute. This indicates whether the element should be focused on page load or, if it is nested inside a dialog or popover element, when the <dialog> or popover is shown.

remarks.para: Only one element inside a document, <dialog> element, or popover may have this attribute specified. If applied to multiple elements, the first focusable one will receive focus.

blockquote.para: Setting this property doesn't set the focus to the associated element: it merely tells the browser to focus to it when the element is inserted in the document. Setting it after the insertion, that is most of the time after the document load, has no visible effect.

HTMLElementBeforetoggle.summary: The beforetoggle event of the interface fires on a {{domxref("Popover_API", "popover", "", "nocode")}} or dialog element just before it is shown or hidden.

remarks.para: This event is cancelable when an element is toggled to open ("show") but not when the element is closing.
Among other things, this event can be used to:

-popover HTML global attribute
-Popover API
-Related event: toggle

HTMLElementBlur.summary: The HTMLElement.blur() method removes keyboard focus from the current element.

HTMLElementChange.summary: The change event is fired for {{HTMLElement("input")}}, {{HTMLElement("select")}}, and {{HTMLElement("textarea")}} elements when the user modifies the element's value. Unlike the event, the change event is not necessarily fired for each alteration to an element's value.

remarks.para: Depending on the kind of element being changed and the way the user interacts with the element, the change event fires at a different moment:
The HTML specification lists the <input> types that should fire the change event.

HTMLElementClick.summary: The HTMLElement.click() method simulates a mouse click on an element. When called on an element, the element's event is fired (unless its disabled attribute is set).

remarks.para:
-Related event handlers-
-
-

HTMLElementCommand.summary: The command event of the interface fires on an element that is controlled via a with valid and values, whenever the button is interacted with (e.g., it is clicked).

HTMLElementContentEditable.summary:
The contentEditable property of
the interface specifies whether or not the element is
editable.

remarks.para: This enumerated attribute can have the following values:

You can use the property to test the
computed boolean value of this property.

If the attribute is missing or its value is invalid, its value is inherited from its parent element: so the element
is editable (or not) based on the parent element.

-
-The contenteditable global attribute.

HTMLElementDataset.summary:
The dataset read-only property
of the interface provides read/write access to custom data attributes
(data-*) on elements. It exposes a map of strings
() with an entry for each data-* attribute.

blockquote.para:
The dataset property itself can be read, but not directly written.
Instead, all writes must be to the individual properties within the
dataset, which in turn represent the data attributes.

remarks.para:
-The HTML data-* class
of global attributes
-Using data attributes
- and

HTMLElementDataset.value:
A .An HTML data-* attribute and its corresponding DOM
dataset.property modify their shared name according to where
they are read or written:Details and examples of converting between the HTML and JavaScript forms is described in more detail in the next section.In addition to the information below, you'll find a how-to guide for using HTML data
attributes in our article Using data attributes.

HTMLElementDir.summary: The HTMLElement.dir property indicates the text writing directionality of the content of the current element. It reflects the element's dir attribute.

remarks.para: Note that if the dir attribute is unspecified, the element itself may still inherit directionality from its parent. However, that inherited directionality is not reflected by this property's value.

The text writing directionality of an element is which direction that text goes (for support of different language systems). Arabic languages and Hebrew are typical languages using the RTL directionality.

-
-HTML dir
global attribute
-CSS direction property
-CSS :dir pseudo-class

HTMLElementDragend.summary: The dragend event is fired when a drag operation ends (by releasing a mouse button or hitting the escape key).

remarks.para: This event is cancelable and may bubble up to the and objects.

-Other drag and drop events:-
-
-
-
-
-

HTMLElementDragenter.summary: The dragenter event is fired when a dragged element or text selection enters a valid drop target. The target object is the immediate user selection (the element directly indicated by the user as the drop target), or the body element.

remarks.para: This event is cancelable and may bubble up to the and objects.

-Other drag and drop events:-
-
-
-
-
-

HTMLElementDraggable.summary: The draggable property of the interface gets and sets a {{jsxref("Boolean")}} primitive indicating if the element is draggable.

remarks.para: It reflects the value of the draggable HTML global attribute.

-draggable HTML global attribute
-HTML Drag and Drop API overview

HTMLElementDraggable.value: A primitive that is true if the element is draggable, false otherwise.

HTMLElementDragleave.summary: The dragleave event is fired when a dragged element or text selection leaves a valid drop target.

remarks.para: This event is not cancelable and may bubble up to the and objects.

-Other drag and drop events:-
-
-
-
-
-

HTMLElementDragover.summary: The dragover event is fired when an element or text selection is being dragged over a valid drop target (every few hundred milliseconds).

remarks.para: This event is cancelable and may bubble up to the and objects.

-Other drag and drop events:-
-
-
-
-
-

HTMLElementDragstart.summary: The dragstart event is fired when the user starts dragging an element or text selection.

remarks.para: This event is cancelable and may bubble up to the and objects.

-Other drag and drop events:-
-
-
-
-
-

HTMLElementDrag.summary: The drag event is fired every few hundred milliseconds as an element or text selection is being dragged by the user.

remarks.para: This event is cancelable and may bubble up to the and objects.

HTMLElementDrop.summary: The drop event is fired when an element or text selection is dropped on a valid drop target. To ensure that the drop event always fires as expected, you should always include a preventDefault() call in the part of your code which handles the dragover event.

remarks.para: This event is cancelable and may bubble up to the and objects.

-Other drag and drop events:-
-
-
-
-
-

HTMLElementEditContext.summary: NOTE Experimental The editContext property of the interface gets and sets an element's associated object.

remarks.para: The {{domxref("EditContext API", "", "", "nocode")}} can be used to build rich text editors on the web that support advanced text input experiences, such as Input Method Editor (IME) composition, emoji picker, or any other platform-specific editing-related UI surfaces.
-The interface.

HTMLElementEnterKeyHint.summary:
The enterKeyHint property is an enumerated property defining
what action label (or icon) to present for the enter key on virtual keyboards.
It reflects the enterkeyhint
HTML global attribute and is an enumerated property, only accepting the following values
as a string:

remarks.para: If no enterKeyHint value has been specified or if it was set to a different value than the allowed ones, it will return an empty string.
-enterkeyhint HTML global attribute

HTMLElementError.summary: The error event is fired on an element when a resource failed to load, or can't be used. For example, if a script has an execution error or an image can't be found or is invalid.

remarks.para: This event is not cancelable and does not bubble.

-Related events-Window: event
-HTMLElement: event

HTMLElementFocus.summary:
The HTMLElement.focus() method sets focus on the specified element, if it can be focused.
The focused element is the element that will receive keyboard and similar events by default.

remarks.para:
By default the browser will scroll the element into view after focusing it, and it may also provide visible indication of the focused element (typically by displaying a "focus ring" around the element).
Parameter options are provided to disable the default scrolling and force visible indication on elements.

- to remove the focus from an element.
- to know which is the currently focused element.

HTMLElementHidden.summary: The property hidden reflects the value of the element's hidden attribute.

remarks.para:
-hidden attribute
-display

HTMLElementHidden.value: This attribute may have one of three values:For details on the usage of this attribute, see the page for the hidden HTML attribute that this property reflects.

HTMLElementHidePopover.summary: The hidePopover() method of the interface hides a popover element (i.e., one that has a valid popover attribute) by removing it from the top layer and styling it with display: none.

remarks.para: When hidePopover() is called on a showing element with the popover attribute, a event will be fired, followed by the popover being hidden, and then the event firing. If the element is already hidden, an error is thrown.
-Popover API

HTMLElementInert.summary: The property inert reflects the value of the element's inert attribute. It is a boolean value that, when present, makes the browser "ignore" user input events for the element, including focus events and events from assistive technologies. The browser may also ignore page search and text selection in the element. This can be useful when building UIs such as modals where you would want to "trap" the focus inside the modal when it's visible.

remarks.para: Note that if the inert attribute is unspecified, the element itself may still inherit inertness from its parent. However, that inherited inertness is not reflected by this property's value. Explicitly setting the property to false cannot revert inertness inherited from the parent.

-Global attribute: inert
-
-dialog
-CSS interactivity property

HTMLElementInert.value: A Boolean which is true if the element is inert; otherwise, the value is false.

HTMLElementInnerText.summary: The innerText property of the interface represents the rendered text content of a node and its descendants.

remarks.para:
As a getter, it approximates the text the user would get if they highlighted the contents of the element with the cursor and then copied it to the clipboard.
As a setter this will replace the element's children with the given value, converting any line breaks into br elements.

blockquote.para:
innerText is easily confused with , but there are important differences between the two.
Basically, innerText is aware of the rendered appearance of text, while textContent is not.

HTMLElementInnerText.value:
A string representing the rendered text content of an element.If the element itself is not being rendered (for example, is detached from the document or is hidden from view), the returned value is the same as the property.
WARNINGSetting innerText on a node removes all of the node's children and replaces them with a single text node with the given string value.

HTMLElementInputMode.summary: The property inputMode reflects the value of the element's inputmode attribute.

remarks.para: It provides a hint about the type of data that might be entered by the user while editing the element or its contents. This allows the browser to display an appropriate virtual keyboard.
It is used primarily on input elements, but is usable on any element in contenteditable mode.
-inputmode attribute

HTMLElementInputMode.value: This attribute may have one of the following values:For details on the usage of this attribute, see the page for the inputmode HTML attribute that this property reflects.

HTMLElementInterest.summary: CAUTION Non-standard The interest event of the interface is fired on an interest invoker's target element when interest is shown, allowing code to be run in response.

remarks.para:
- event
-Popover API
-Using interest invokers

HTMLElementIsContentEditable.summary:
The HTMLElement.isContentEditable read-only property
returns a boolean value that is true if the contents of the element
are editable; otherwise it returns false.

remarks.para:
-
-The contenteditable global attribute.

HTMLElementLang.summary: The lang property of the interface indicates the base language of an element's attribute values and text content, in the form of a {{glossary("BCP 47 language tag")}}. It reflects the element's lang attribute; the xml:lang attribute does not affect this property.

remarks.para: Note that if the lang attribute is unspecified, the element itself may still inherit the language from its parent. However, that inherited language is not reflected by this property's value.

HTMLElementLang.value: A string. Common examples include "en" for English, "ja" for Japanese, "es" for Spanish and so on. If unspecified, the value is an empty string.

HTMLElementLoad.summary: The load event fires for elements containing a resource when the resource has successfully loaded. Currently, the list of supported HTML elements are: body, embed, iframe, img, link, object, script, style, and track.

blockquote.para: The load event on is actually an alias for the event. Therefore, the load event will only fire on the <body> element once all of the document's resources have loaded or errored. However, for the sake of clarity, it is recommended that the event handler is attached to the window object directly rather than on HTMLBodyElement.

remarks.para: This event is not cancelable and does not bubble.

-Related events-Window: event
-Window: event

HTMLElementLoseinterest.summary: CAUTION Non-standard The loseinterest event of the interface is fired on the target element of an interest invoker when interest is lost, allowing code to be run in response.

remarks.para: This event is normally cancelable, except when the user hits the <kbd>Esc</kbd> key to lose interest in all interest invokers contained in the document.

- event
-Popover API
-Using interest invokers

HTMLElementNonce.summary: The nonce property of the interface returns the cryptographic number used once that is used by Content Security Policy to determine whether a given fetch will be allowed to proceed.

remarks.para: In later implementations, elements only expose their nonce attribute to scripts (and not to side-channels like CSS attribute selectors).

HTMLElementOffsetHeight.summary: The offsetHeight read-only property of the interface returns the height of an element, including vertical padding and borders, as an integer.

remarks.para: Typically, offsetHeight is a measurement in pixels of the element's CSS height, including any borders, padding, and horizontal scrollbars (if rendered). It does not include the height of pseudo-elements such as ::before or ::after. For the document body object, the measurement includes total linear content height instead of the element's CSS height. Floated elements extending below other linear content are ignored.
If the element is hidden (for example, by setting style.display on the element or one of its ancestors to "none"), then 0 is returned.

-Determining the dimensions of elements
-
-
-
-
-
-

HTMLElementOffsetLeft.summary: The offsetLeft read-only property of the interface returns the number of pixels that the upper left corner of the current element is offset to the left within the node.

remarks.para: For block-level elements, offsetTop, offsetLeft, offsetWidth, and offsetHeight describe the border box of an element relative to the offsetParent.

However, for inline-level elements (such as <span>) that can wrap from one line to the next, offsetTop and offsetLeft describe the positions of the first border box (use to get its width and height), while offsetWidth and offsetHeight describe the dimensions of the bounding border box (use to get its position). Therefore, a box with the left, top, width and height of offsetLeft, offsetTop, offsetWidth and offsetHeight will not be a bounding box for a span with wrapped text.

-Determining the dimensions of elements
-
-
-
-
-
-

HTMLElementOffsetParent.summary:
The HTMLElement.offsetParent read-only property returns a
reference to the element which is the closest (nearest in the containment hierarchy)
positioned ancestor element.

remarks.para: A positioned ancestor might be:
If there is no positioned ancestor element, the body is returned.

blockquote.para:
offsetParent returns null in the following
situations:

remarks.para:
offsetParent is useful because
and
are relative to its padding edge.

HTMLElementOffsetParent.value: An object reference to the element in which the current element is offset.

HTMLElementOffsetTop.summary: The offsetTop read-only property of the interface returns the distance from the outer border of the current element (including its margin) to the top padding edge of the , the closest positioned ancestor element.

remarks.para:
-Determining the dimensions of elements
-
-
-
-
-
-

HTMLElementOffsetWidth.summary: The offsetWidth read-only property of the interface returns the layout width of an element as an integer.

remarks.para: Typically, offsetWidth is a measurement in pixels of the element's CSS width, including any borders, padding, and vertical scrollbars (if rendered). It does not include the width of pseudo-elements such as ::before or ::after.
If the element is hidden (for example, by setting style.display on the element or one of its ancestors to "none"), then 0 is returned.

-Determining the dimensions of elements
-
-
-
-
-
-

HTMLElementOuterText.summary:
The outerText property of the interface returns the same value as .
When used as a setter it replaces the whole current node with the given text (this differs from innerText, which replaces the content inside the current node).

remarks.para: See for more information and examples showing how both properties are used as getters.

HTMLElementOuterText.value: A string representing the rendered text content of an element and its descendants.If the element itself is not being rendered (for example, is detached from the document or is hidden from view), the returned value is the same as the property.When used as a setter it replaces the current node with the given text, converting any line breaks into br elements.

HTMLElementPopover.summary: The popover property of the interface gets and sets an element's popover state via JavaScript ("auto", "hint", or "manual"), and can be used for feature detection.

remarks.para: It reflects the value of the popover global HTML attribute.

-popover HTML global attribute
-Popover API

HTMLElementPopover.value: An enumerated value; possible values are:

HTMLElementShowPopover.summary: The showPopover() method of the interface shows a {{domxref("Popover_API", "popover", "", "nocode")}} element (i.e., one that has a valid popover attribute) by adding it to the top layer.

remarks.para: When showPopover() is called on an element with the popover attribute that is currently hidden, a event will be fired, followed by the popover showing, and then the event firing. If the element is already showing, an error will be thrown.
-Popover API

HTMLElementSpellcheck.summary: The spellcheck property of the interface represents a boolean value that controls the spell-checking hint. It is available on all HTML elements, though it doesn't affect all of them.

remarks.para: It reflects the value of the spellcheck HTML global attribute.
-spellcheck HTML global attribute

HTMLElementSpellcheck.value: A boolean value that is true if the spelling and grammar of the text content in the element may be checked, false otherwise.

HTMLElementStyle.summary:
The read-only style property of the interface returns the inline style of an element in the form of a live object.
This object can be used to get and set the inline styles of an element.

remarks.para:
-Using dynamic styling information
-
-
-
-HTML style attribute

HTMLElementStyle.value:
A live object.
NOTEEarlier versions of the specification returned a (from which is derived).
See the browser compatibility table for browser support information.Although the style property itself is read-only in the sense that you can't replace the CSSStyleProperties object, you can still assign to the style property directly, which is equivalent to assigning to its property. You can also modify the CSSStyleProperties object using the and methods.

HTMLElementTabIndex.summary:
The tabIndex property of the
interface represents the tab order of the current element.

remarks.para: Tab order is as follows:
Elements that are disabled do not participate in the tabbing order.

Values don't need to be sequential, nor must they begin with any particular value. They
may even be negative, though each browser trims very large values.

-Accessibility of keyboard-navigable JavaScript widgets
-The HTML
tabindex
global attribute.

HTMLElementTitle.summary:
The HTMLElement.title property
represents the title of the element: the text usually displayed in a 'tooltip' popup
when the mouse is over the node.

remarks.para:
-The HTML title
global attribute.

HTMLElementTogglePopover.summary: The togglePopover() method of the interface toggles a {{domxref("Popover_API", "popover", "", "nocode")}} element (i.e., one that has a valid popover attribute) between the hidden and showing states.

remarks.para: When togglePopover() is called on an element with the popover attribute:

-popover HTML global attribute
-Popover API

HTMLElementTogglePopover.returns: true if the popup is open after the call, and false otherwise.None () may be returned in older browser versions (see browser compatibility).

HTMLElementToggle.summary: The toggle event of the interface fires on a {{domxref("Popover_API", "popover", "", "nocode")}} element, dialog element, or details element just after it is shown or hidden.

remarks.para: This event is not cancelable.

-popover HTML global attribute
-Popover API
-Related event: beforetoggle

HTMLElementTranslate.summary: The translate property of the interface indicates whether an element's attribute values and the values of its node children are to be translated when the page is localized, or whether to leave them unchanged.

remarks.para: It reflects the value of the translate HTML global attribute.
-translate HTML global attribute

HTMLElementTranslate.value: A boolean value that is true if an element's attribute values and the values of its node children are to be translated when the page is localized, false otherwise.

HTMLElementVirtualKeyboardPolicy.summary: NOTE Experimental The virtualKeyboardPolicy property of the interface gets and sets a string indicating the on-screen virtual keyboard behavior on devices such as tablets, mobile phones, or other devices where a hardware keyboard may not be available, if the element's content is editable (for example, it is an {{htmlelement("input")}} or {{htmlelement("textarea")}} element, or an element with the contenteditable attribute set).

remarks.para: It reflects the value of the virtualkeyboardpolicy HTML global attribute.
-virtualkeyboardpolicy HTML global attribute

HTMLElementVirtualKeyboardPolicy.value: An enumerated value; possible values are:

HTMLElementWritingSuggestions.summary: The writingSuggestions property of the interface is a string indicating if browser-provided writing suggestions should be enabled under the scope of the element or not.

remarks.para: It reflects the value of the writingsuggestions HTML global attribute.
-writingsuggestions HTML global attribute

HTMLElementWritingSuggestions.value: An enumerated value; possible values are:
